commonMistakes: Training the same muscle before full recovery

faqs.question: How do I know if I've recovered?
faqs.answer: No muscle soreness, good energy, ability to lift the same or more weight.

faqs.question: Can I speed up recovery?
faqs.answer: Yes, through adequate sleep, protein, hydration, and light stretching.

faqs.question: What if I train before recovery?
faqs.answer: Weaker performance, higher injury risk, and less muscle growth.

flexibility-score-calculator.title: Flexibility Score Calculator - Assessment and Test
flexibility-score-calculator.description: Assess your joint and muscle flexibility level with simple, scientific tests. Free online flexibility and mobility tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Flexibility Score Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Score = Average of different flexibility test scores
howItWorks.explanation: This tool assesses your body flexibility through several simple tests targeting different areas. Flexibility is important for injury prevention and improving athletic performance and daily life.

steps.name: Sit and Reach Test
steps.text: Measure the distance you can reach past your toes

steps.name: Shoulder Flexibility Test
steps.text: Measure the distance between your hands behind your back

steps.name: Hip Flexion Test
steps.text: Measure the maximum angle of hip flexion

useCases.title: Performance Improvement
useCases.description: Flexibility improves range of motion and athletic performance

seoTips: Perform tests after a light warm-up
Don't push to pain, stop at stretch sensation
Compare your results to yourself, not others
Consistency in stretching is more important than intensity
commonMistakes: Pushing hard to reach higher numbers

faqs.question: How do I improve my flexibility?
faqs.answer: Through daily stretching for 10-15 minutes, and patience as improvement is slow.

faqs.question: Does flexibility improve with age?
faqs.answer: It naturally decreases, but regular stretching slows this and improves it.

faqs.question: When should I stretch?
faqs.answer: Dynamic stretching before exercise, static stretching after or at a separate time.

howItWorks.title: How the Recovery Time Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Recovery Time = Base Time × Muscle Size Factor × Intensity Factor / Experience Factor
howItWorks.explanation: This tool estimates the time needed for your muscles to fully recover before training them again. Recovery time depends on the size of the muscle group trained, workout intensity, and your training experience. Adequate recovery is essential for muscle growth and injury prevention.

steps.text: Choose the size of the muscle group you trained

steps.name: Set Intensity
steps.text: Select how intense your workout was

useCases.title: Workout Scheduling

useCases.title: Overtraining Prevention
useCases.description: Avoid training muscles before they have fully recovered

useCases.title: Optimal Growth
useCases.description: Ensure muscles have recovered fully to maximize training adaptations

seoTips: Large muscle groups (legs, back) typically need 72+ hours recovery
Small muscle groups (biceps, triceps, calves) may only need 48 hours
Quality sleep significantly accelerates the recovery process
Post-workout protein consumption supports muscle repair
commonMistakes: Training the same muscle group before it has fully recovered
Ignoring signs of incomplete recovery (soreness, weakness, fatigue)
Believing more frequent training always leads to better results
Neglecting sleep, nutrition, and hydration in the recovery process

faqs.question: How do I know if I have recovered?
faqs.answer: Muscle soreness is gone, energy levels are normal, and you can lift equal or greater weight than the previous session.

faqs.question: Can I speed up recovery?
faqs.answer: Yes, through adequate sleep (7-9 hours), proper nutrition (especially protein), hydration, and light stretching or active recovery.

faqs.question: What happens if I train before recovery?
faqs.answer: You may experience weaker performance, increased injury risk, and potentially less muscle growth over time.

seoTips: Warm up with light activity before testing for accurate results
Test flexibility at the same time of day for consistent comparisons
Flexibility improves gradually - expect changes over weeks, not days
Static stretching after workouts is most effective for flexibility gains
commonMistakes: Testing flexibility without warming up first (cold muscles test lower)
Bouncing or forcing the stretch instead of holding steady
Comparing your flexibility to people with different body types
Only stretching muscle groups that are already flexible

faqs.question: Can everyone become flexible?
faqs.answer: Yes, but the rate and extent depend on genetics, age, and consistency. Everyone can improve from their starting point.

faqs.question: How often should I stretch?
faqs.answer: For improvement, stretch at least 3-4 times per week. Daily stretching provides the best results.

faqs.question: Does flexibility decrease with age?
faqs.answer: Yes, naturally, but regular stretching significantly slows the decline and can even improve flexibility at any age.
